thread.title: Democratic debate: Where can I watch on TV and online?
thread.title_full: Democratic debate: Where can I watch on TV and online? | OregonLive.com

author: Michelle Brence | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Democratic debate: Where can I watch on TV and online?
text:
Now it's the Democrats' turn. Five candidates will take the stage Tuesday at 5:30 p.m. Pacific time in Las Vegas for the first Democratic presidential debate of the campaign. Here's what you need to know to watch, listen and learn more in the Portland metro area.
Who's debating? The candidates are former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, former Virginia Sen. Jim Webb and former Rhode Island Gov. Lincoln Chafee.
What about Joe Biden? CNN invited the vice president to participate but indicated Monday that he wasn't expected to join in.
Where to watch on TV: CNN and OregonLive . You'll find the network on Xfinity Channels 44 and 744, Dish Network Channel 200, DIRECTV Channel 202, and Prism Channels 202 and 1202. CNN will also show the debate on CNN en Espanol and CNN International.
Live streams: We'll live-stream the debate at OregonLive . CNN will live-stream the debates at CNN.com , CNN.com/politics and on CNN mobile apps .
Where to listen on the radio: Westwood One News stations will air the debate. In Portland, tune into KXL-FM (101.1) or KEX-AM (1190).
What time? The debate will run 5:30 to 8 p.m. Tuesday, Oct. 13, Pacific time.
Local live blog: Join Jeff Mapes , The Oregonian/OregonLive's senior politics reporter, at OregonLive.com during the debate for live reaction and analysis. And come back to oregonlive.com/politics Wednesday morning for Mapes' top takeaways from the debate.
Sponsors: CNN and Facebook
Moderator: Anderson Cooper will moderate, and Dana Bush and Juan Carlos Lopez will also ask questions. Don Lemon will pose questions submitted via Facebook and Instagram.
Venue: Wynn Las Vegas, a hotel on the Las Vegas Strip
Join in: You can submit questions for consideration using Facebook and Instagram . On Twitter, follow #DEMDEBATE.
What's different from the Republican debates? The Democrats have far fewer candidates, so there's no "kids' table" debate for second-tier candidates.
More:
